body: Up - it's really urgent, because it makes MLFlow Projects completely unusable.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
It's not stale - it's just ignored...
Thank you for interacting with this issue! Removing the stale label!
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
@jaklan sorry for the delay!! To clarify, does this problem occur specifically with docker-based projects (e.g. when `mlflow run`-ing a project whose MLproject file contains a `docker_env` field)?

Got it, thanks for the clarification - it's surprising to me as AFAICT we basically execute a `COPY` dockerfile command to copy files into the container, so .dockerignore should be honored: https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/361f1ecc17e96edd1e6d2d8f10345d986ad45192/mlflow/projects/__init__.py#L660-L674

Happy to help guide further investigation if anyone's able to / interested in taking a look, will otherwise see if I can make time at some point to take a look

@smurching we've replaced MLFlow Projects with Kedro (it's much more advanced) and don't play with it for months, so I haven't tested that issue since the original post. It should be quite simple to reproduce anyway - just put .dockerignore in the main project folder and check if it is honored.

I experience the same issue. I hope I found the reason for this.

It seems to me that the .dockerignore file is not honored in python docker, when `fileobj` or `custom_context` is passed to `client.images.build`: https://github.com/docker/docker-py/blob/26d8045ffa99ec402e451cde67415b14b13cc95a/docker/api/build.py#L138-L162

I don't think docker itself takes care of the build context with the `COPY` command in the dockerfile.

When I understand the mlflow implementation with this custom context correctly, these steps are taken:
1. A hard coded dockerfile is specified on top of the base image
2. A custom build context is build by
    1. copying the whole directory into a temp directory
    2. Adding the specified dockerfile from above
    3. Wrapping everything up into a temp tar file (the custom context)
3. docker build is called with the custom context

I might miss some hidden functionality of how these contexts are used, but it seems that when specifying a custom context, it is assumed that the .dockerignore or any other relevant aspect for the context is taken care of.

Ideally the dockerignore would be read before any copying happens, since this seems to heavily slow down everything in case something like a `.venv` is in the work directory

I have encountered the same issue. Here is how I found out .dockerignore was not honored:
1. Place both MLproject and .dockerignore files in the project's root directory. 
2. Set MLproject to use docker_env.
3. Execute `mlflow run .` in the project's root dir and wait for the run to complete.
4. Examine the files inside `/mlflow/projects/code` in the newly built image with this command `docker run -it --entrypoint /bin/bash [docker_image]`

Every file and folder in my project's root dir, including what's specified in `.dockerignore`, were found inside the new image.

Honoring `.dockerignore` is very important as `.dockerignore` is used to exclude unnecessary files to reduce image size (especially when running in Kubernetes) and to prevent sensitive information from getting into new images. One should, at least, have `.git` in the `.dockerignore` to prevent building your entire git history into new images.

Please prioritize fixing this issue as it's a deal breaker for a lot of use cases.

+1 would like to see this fixed. I have some permission issues with .git files causing permission issues when mlflow creates the docker image. Would have been nice if could have used dockerignore to get around this.
